texts.shortText: Small, jet-black worm that characteristically burrows into encrusting coralline algae, forming colonies of regularlyâ€“spaced individuals. Only the first few segments of each worm project and are visible. The head is bluntly rounded and bears a pair of elongate, grooved palps and behind this each of the first 4 body segments bears a pair of long, thin, thread-like, black gills.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to Algoa Bay.

Very characteristic species both in terms of the unusual jet black colour and the specialised habitat of burrowing into plates of thick coralline algae. Very common in this habitat, both intertidally and on shallow reefs. The palps are extended to gather food particles from the passing water and the gills project from the burrow for gas exchange.

Most species in this group can reproduce both asexually and sexually.

This species is well known to expand its colonies by fragmenting asexually into anterior and posterior halves, each of which then regenerates its missing portions. All individuals appear to fragment before later undergoing sexual reproduction as adults. At that point eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. They take about two years to reach sexual maturity.

Unlikely to be confused with other local species, although a second introduced species D. fewkesi has been found in Cape Town harbour. That species is also black, but constructs its own characteristic hemispherical masses of coralline tubes, rather than burrowing into coralline algae.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 70).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 502).

Gibson, PH (1977). Reproduction in the cirratulid polychaetes Dodecaceria concharum and D. pulchra. Journal of Zoology, 182(1), 89-102.
